<form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkAnswer('module4_mcq_q28')" data-correct-answer="B">
  <strong style="display: block;">Which situation illustrates a violation of the CAPM assumptions?</strong>

  <label><input type="radio" name="module4_mcq_q28" value="A"> A. Investors have homogeneous expectations about returns and risks.</label><br>
  <label><input type="radio" name="module4_mcq_q28" value="B"> B. Some investors face borrowing constraints and cannot access the risk-free rate for leverage.</label><br>
  <label><input type="radio" name="module4_mcq_q28" value="C"> C. All assets are publicly traded and infinitely divisible.</label><br>
  <label><input type="radio" name="module4_mcq_q28" value="D"> D. The market portfolio is assumed to be mean-variance efficient.</label><br>
  <label><input type="radio" name="module4_mcq_q28" value="E"> E. Expected returns are assumed to increase linearly with beta.</label><br>
</form>

<div id="feedback-module4_mcq_q28" class="feedback" data-status="" style="display:none;">
✅ Correct: B. CAPM assumes investors can freely borrow and lend at the risk-free rate. In reality, borrowing constraints and different lending/borrowing rates mean this assumption is violated, which limits the model’s accuracy in practice.
